channel.title: Health Care
channel.description: The state of health care, health insurance, new medical research, disease prevention, and drug treatments. Interviews, news, and commentary from NPR's correspondents. Subscribe to podcasts.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: How Much Is That MRI, Really? Massachusetts Shines A Light
item.description: A state law now requires insurers to reveal prices of their medical tests, and the variation is amazing, bargain hunters say. An MRI of the back is $614 at one place, $1,800 at another.
item.content:encoded:
A state law now requires insurers to reveal prices of their medical tests, and the variation is amazing, bargain hunters say. An MRI of the back is $614 at one place, $1,800 at another.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Martha Bebinger

item.title: Employers Can't Skip Insurance Coverage For Hospitalization
item.description: Many companies planned to offer health insurance without hospital coverage because it met requirements of a "minimum value" formula. But the Treasury Department says those plans aren't legal.
item.content:encoded:
Many companies planned to offer health insurance without hospital coverage because it met requirements of a "minimum value" formula. But the Treasury Department says those plans aren't legal.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Jay Hancock

item.title: Doctor: Helping A Patient Die Will Never Become Routine
item.description: Robert Siegel talks to Dr. Katherine Morris about assisted suicide. Morris assisted in the deaths of patients in Oregon and has been party to a lawsuit in New Mexico for the right to assist another.
item.content:encoded:
Robert Siegel talks to Dr. Katherine Morris about assisted suicide. Morris assisted in the deaths of patients in Oregon and has been party to a lawsuit in New Mexico for the right to assist another.

» E-Mail This

item.title: High-Profile Case Brings New Attention To Oregon's Assisted Suicide Law
item.description: Over the weekend, Brittany Maynard used Oregon's Death with Dignity law to end her own life. Since Oregon's law first passed in 1994, hundreds have used it to prevent suffering at the ends of life.
item.content:encoded:
Over the weekend, Brittany Maynard used Oregon's Death with Dignity law to end her own life. Since Oregon's law first passed in 1994, hundreds have used it to prevent suffering at the ends of life.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Kristian Foden-Vencil

item.title: Brain Training May Help Calm The Storms Of Schizophrenia
item.description: Drugs can tamp down the hallucinations and delusions associated with schizophrenia, but at a cost. A newer approach to treatment aims to teach people to tune out the distractions instead.
item.content:encoded:
Drugs can tamp down the hallucinations and delusions associated with schizophrenia, but at a cost. A newer approach to treatment aims to teach people to tune out the distractions instead.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Amy Standen

item.title: Seeing Red During Breast Cancer Awareness Month
item.description: Decades of effort to raise awareness of breast cancer hasn't helped to reduce the death toll once it spreads. One woman living with metastatic breast cancer says it's way past time for a change.
item.content:encoded:
Decades of effort to raise awareness of breast cancer hasn't helped to reduce the death toll once it spreads. One woman living with metastatic breast cancer says it's way past time for a change.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Anne Loeser

item.title: Ebola Researchers Banned From Medical Meeting In New Orleans
item.description: One of the top scientific conferences on tropical diseases will take place without the people who have the most recent and direct experience with Ebola in West Africa.
item.content:encoded:
One of the top scientific conferences on tropical diseases will take place without the people who have the most recent and direct experience with Ebola in West Africa.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Jason Beaubien

item.title: Medicare Concedes, Agrees To Pay For Woman's Home Health Care
item.description: A 78-year-old Vermont woman has won the latest skirmish in her long-running battle with Medicare. The agency agreed to pay for home health care coverage even though she remains disabled.
item.content:encoded:
A 78-year-old Vermont woman has won the latest skirmish in her long-running battle with Medicare. The agency agreed to pay for home health care coverage even though she remains disabled.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Susan Jaffe

item.title: What A Brush With SARS Taught A Doctor About Ebola
item.description: A young doctor put on a protective suit so he could examine a man who might be sick with SARS. It was hard to tell who was more frightened: the doctor or the patient.
item.content:encoded:
A young doctor put on a protective suit so he could examine a man who might be sick with SARS. It was hard to tell who was more frightened: the doctor or the patient.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: John Henning Schumann

item.title: Emory Hospital Shares Lessons Learned On Ebola Care
item.description: The same Atlanta hospital that treated the first U.S. Ebola patient in August discharged its fourth patient Tuesday. All survived. Patients in isolation need extra emotional support, the team says.
item.content:encoded:
The same Atlanta hospital that treated the first U.S. Ebola patient in August discharged its fourth patient Tuesday. All survived. Patients in isolation need extra emotional support, the team says.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Jim Burress

item.title: Home Health Workers Struggle For Better Pay And Health Insurance
item.description: Home health care aides often toil for low pay and in jobs without benefits, including health insurance. A million more home health care workers will be needed to meet demand over the next decade.
item.content:encoded:
Home health care aides often toil for low pay and in jobs without benefits, including health insurance. A million more home health care workers will be needed to meet demand over the next decade.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Sarah Jane Tribble

item.title: Insurers May Cover Costly Hepatitis C Drugs Only For The Very Ill
item.description: Many insurers are restricting access to new drugs that are easier to take and that promise higher cure rates because the price tags can run $95,000 or more.
item.content:encoded:
Many insurers are restricting access to new drugs that are easier to take and that promise higher cure rates because the price tags can run $95,000 or more.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Michelle Andrews

item.title: With Obamacare, More Millennials Are Going To The Doctor, Sort Of
item.description: Once young adults started getting coverage through their parents, they started getting checkups more often, a study finds. But they still may need help filling a prescription.
item.content:encoded:
Once young adults started getting coverage through their parents, they started getting checkups more often, a study finds. But they still may need help filling a prescription.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Maanvi Singh

item.title: Disabled Vermont Woman Who Led Class-Action Suit Sues Medicare Again
item.description: A legally blind woman who has led a fight to make Medicare pay for care even when patients' medical conditions don't improve is in court to get Medicare payment for her own home care.
item.content:encoded:
A legally blind woman who has led a fight to make Medicare pay for care even when patients' medical conditions don't improve is in court to get Medicare payment for her own home care.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Susan Jaffe

item.title: In The Hospital, A Bad Translation Can Destroy A Life
item.description: When patient and doctor don't speak the same language, it's not enough to have an ad hoc interpreter. You need an adult fluent in both languages — who can also cut through medical jargon.
item.content:encoded:
When patient and doctor don't speak the same language, it's not enough to have an ad hoc interpreter. You need an adult fluent in both languages — who can also cut through medical jargon.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Kristian Foden-Vencil
